default.prompt: Which built-in module is used to detect if the app is running on iOS or Android?
default.explanation: The Platform module provides a 'OS' property that returns either 'ios' or 'android'.
default.interviewTip: You can also use it to check the version of the OS using Platform.Version.

default.prompt: How can you use the Platform module to apply different styles in a single object?
options: You must use separate CSS files
default.explanation: Platform.select is the cleanest way to provide platform-specific values for styles, props, or logic.
default.interviewTip: Platform.select is often preferred for readability when handling more than two platform variations (like 'native' vs 'web').

default.prompt: If you have two files, 'Button.ios.js' and 'Button.android.js', how do you import the button?
options: You can't have two files with the same name
default.explanation: React Native's bundler (Metro) automatically detects the extension and picks the correct file for the platform you are building for.
default.interviewTip: This is the most scalable way to handle large differences in component implementation between platforms.

options: To check if the user is using a stylus
To detect if the iOS device is an iPad
To check if the app is running on any tablet
To check if the screen has a notch
default.explanation: isPad is an iOS-specific boolean to help you adjust layouts for tablet-sized screens.
default.interviewTip: For a cross-platform tablet check, you usually look at the screen width via Dimensions.

default.prompt: How do you handle shadows on Android, since 'shadowColor' only works for iOS?
options: Shadows are not possible on Android
default.explanation: Android uses the native 'elevation' property to create shadows based on the Material Design spec.
default.interviewTip: Because elevation and iOS shadow properties are so different, libraries like 'react-native-shadow-2' are often used for consistency.

default.explanation: On Android, it returns the integer API level. On iOS, it returns a string representing the OS version.
default.interviewTip: This is useful for enabling/disabling features that are only available in newer OS versions.

default.prompt: Which component is strictly for Android to show a date picker?
options: React Native does not have one
default.explanation: Legacy RN had platform-specific pickers. Modern apps use 'react-native-datetimepicker' which wraps the native pickers for both.
default.interviewTip: Always prefer community-maintained libraries for pickers to ensure they stay up-to-date with OS changes.

default.explanation: HIG defines how iOS apps should look and feel (e.g., navigation on the left, centered titles).
default.interviewTip: Mentioning HIG (iOS) and Material Design (Android) shows you care about native UX.

default.prompt: How do you set the color of the status bar (clock/battery area) on Android?
options: Using the <StatusBar> component with the 'backgroundColor' prop
default.explanation: The <StatusBar> component allows you to control the look of the device's status bar.
default.interviewTip: Note that 'backgroundColor' is Android-only; on iOS, you can only change the 'barStyle' (light or dark).

options: To check if the app is playing a movie
To detect if the app is running on Apple TV or Android TV
To connect to a smart TV
default.explanation: React Native supports TV platforms, and this boolean helps adjust the UI for '10-foot' interfaces (remote control navigation).
default.interviewTip: Focus management is the biggest challenge when building for TV.

default.prompt: Which touchable component provides a 'native' ripple effect on Android?
default.explanation: TouchableNativeFeedback uses the native ripple effect found in Android Material Design.
default.interviewTip: You can also achieve this in <Pressable> using the 'android_ripple' prop.

default.prompt: How do you handle 'Back' navigation on Android vs iOS?
options: Both use a hardware back button
Android has a hardware/system back button; iOS relies on on-screen buttons or a swipe gesture
Both use the same software button in the header
default.explanation: React Native provides the BackHandler API specifically for Android's system back button.
default.interviewTip: React Navigation handles most of this for you, but custom listeners are sometimes needed for exit-confirmation dialogs.

default.prompt: In CSS/Styles, what is 'marginVertical' a shorthand for?
default.explanation: React Native provides several 'shorthand' style props like marginVertical and marginHorizontal that don't exist in standard web CSS.
default.interviewTip: These shorthands make your StyleSheet objects smaller and easier to read.

options: Google's design language for Android and the web
default.explanation: Material Design uses specific shadows (elevation), animations, and layouts that are standard for Android users.
default.interviewTip: Good cross-platform apps often subtly change their components to match these specs (e.g., center-aligned headers on iOS vs left-aligned on Android).

default.prompt: How do you import a file specifically for the Web version of your RN app?
default.explanation: React Native for Web supports the .web.js extension, allowing you to use DOM-specific libraries only in the browser version.
default.interviewTip: This is great for using 'window' or 'document' safely without breaking the mobile build.

default.prompt: Which property is used on iOS to allow text to be scaled by system accessibility settings?
default.explanation: allowFontScaling (true by default) ensures the app respects the user's preference for larger text in the system settings.
default.interviewTip: Always test your layouts with 'Large Text' enabled to ensure your UI doesn't break for users with visual impairments.

options: To detect if the user has Dark Mode or Light Mode enabled at the system level
To change the primary color of the app
default.explanation: The Appearance module (or useColorScheme hook) allows you to adapt your styles to the system-wide theme.
default.interviewTip: Modern apps should support Dark Mode to provide a premium native feel.
